entry.title: loadJson function in Tsup sourceÂ code.
Meetings â€“ The Real Boss Fight
entry.summary: If programming is about solving problems, then meetings are about talking about solving problems. Or, if weâ€™re being honest, sometimes just talking full stop (some people love the sound of their own voices). Donâ€™t get me wrong... some meetings are genuinely useful. Sprint planning, architecture chats, roadmap sessions that actually go somewhere. But letâ€™s face it: not all meetings are cut from the same cloth. Some are just glorified calendar clutter. If I had a pound for every time Iâ€™ve heard that (or thought it silently while slowly dying inside) Iâ€™d probably have enough to retire. Or at the very least, a fancy coffee with some oat milk nonsense (Sorry! I just prefer lots of black coffee but that's just me). You log onto a 15 minute Teams call with ten other people. No oneâ€™s quite sure wâ€¦

entry.title: ğŸŒ Global Error Handling in ASP.NET Core with Custom Middleware and Serilog
7 Ways to Speed Up Your Python Code
entry.summary:
ğŸš€ Writing efficient Python code is essential for developers working on performance-sensitive tasks like data processing, web applications, or machine learning. In this post, you'll explore 7 proven techniques to boost Python performance â€” with examples, explanations, and quick wins you can implement right away. Before making changes, identify the real bottlenecks using profiling tools: import cProfile
def main(): # Your code ...
cProfile.run('main()')
ğŸ” Use tools like timeit, line_profiler, or snakeviz to dig deeper. âš ï¸ Don't optimize blindly. Focus only on the actual slow spots. Pythonâ€™s built-ins (written in C) are much faster than custom logic: # Slower version s = 0 for i in range(1000000): s += i
# Faster version s = sum(range(1000000))
Also leverage: map() and filtâ€¦

entry.title: Build a Stack, Not a Startup: Creating Resilient One-Person Businesses
entry.summary:
A solo founderâ€™s guide to designing systems that scale without chaosâ€”and outlast your energy.
â€œStartups chase growth. Stacks chase stabilityâ€. Thatâ€™s the shift. When youâ€™re a solo founder, the traditional playbook stops making sense. Youâ€™re not managing teams. Youâ€™re not pitching VCs. not something you want to escape from. This article is about designing that thing: Startups are designed for velocity. If a startup is a rocketship fueled by scale, a solo business stack is a self-sustaining ecosystemâ€”quietly running under its own weight. The goal isnâ€™t to do more. Itâ€™s to build less often, and benefit longer. The big mindset shift? You stop optimizing for explosive growth.
What Is a Stack (When Youâ€™re a Solo Founder)?
Your stack isnâ€™t just your tools. architecture of how â€¦

entry.title: Oracle 23ai â€” Applying Grid Infrastructure Patches via GUI(Zero-Downtime)
entry.summary:
In Oracle 23ai, it is possible to apply patches to the Grid software using the gridSetup.sh script through a wizard-based graphical interface. This process can also be performed with zero downtime. In this guide, we aim to apply Release Update 23.6 to Grid Infrastructure version 23.5. Currently, Grid Infrastructure 23.5 is running: [grid@OL810 ~]$ sqlplus "/as sysasm" SQL*Plus: Release 23.0.0.0.0 â€“ for Oracle Cloud and Engineered Systems on Wed Nov 27 12:57:14 2024 Version 23.5.0.24.07 Copyright Â© 1982, 2024, Oracle. All rights reserved. Connected to: Oracle Database 23ai Enterprise Edition Release 23.0.0.0.0 â€“ for Oracle Cloud and Engineered Systems Version 23.5.0.24.07 SQL>
To apply the patch, the Grid Infrastructure software version 23.6 must first be installed as software only.
â€¦

entry.title: PHP array_map Function: Detailed Guide
Linear container
entry.summary:
Linear Container Implementation
Linear containers are data structures that allow sequential access to elements. They are primarily implemented using arrays and include several types: ArrayList, Vector, List, LinkedList, Deque, Queue, and Stack. Linear containers are designed for fast data access, enabling operations like adding, deleting, updating, and querying elements with a single bytecode instruction at runtime.
Class Name Characteristics and Recommended Use Cases
ArrayList Dynamic array, occupies a contiguous memory space. Recommended when frequent element access is needed.
List Singly linked list, non-contiguous memory. Recommended for frequent insertions/deletions using a singly linked list.
LinkedList Doubly linked list, non-contiguous memory. Recommended for frequent â€¦
